children.description: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Write an inequality of the form x > c or x < c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent and analyze quantitative relationships between dependent and independent variables.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve word problems leading to equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Solve equations of these forms fluently. Compare an algebraic solution to an arithmetic solution, identifying the sequence of the operations used in each approach.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Graph the solution set of the inequality and interpret it in the context of the problem.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Know and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form x = p and x = p, where p is a positive rational number. Evaluate square roots of small perfect squares and cube roots of small perfect cubes. Know that 2 is irrational.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times an integer power of 10 to estimate very large or very small quantities, and to express how many times as much one is than the other.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very large or very small quantities (e.g., use millimeters per year for seafloor spreading). Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Work with radicals and integer exponents.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Graph proportional relationships, interpreting the unit rate as the slope of the graph. Compare two different proportional relationships represented in different ways.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the coordinate plane; derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand the connections between proportional relationships, lines, and linear equations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve linear equations with rational number coefficients, including equations whose solutions require expanding expressions using the distributive property and collecting like terms.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve linear equations in one variable.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that solutions to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to points of intersection of their graphs, because points of intersection satisfy both equations simultaneously.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing the equations. Solve simple cases by inspection.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems leading to two linear equations in two variables.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Analyze and solve linear equations and pairs of simultaneous linear equations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Recognize a statistical question as one that anticipates variability in the data related to the question and accounts for it in the answers.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Recognize that a measure of center for a numerical data set summarizes all of its values with a single number, while a measure of variation describes how its values vary with a single number.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Develop understanding of statistical variability.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Reporting the number of observations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Describing the nature of the attribute under investigation, including how it was measured and its units of measurement.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Giving quantitative measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (interquartile range and/or mean absolute deviation), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Relating the choice of measures of center and variability to the shape of the data distribution and the context in which the data were gathered.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Summarize and describe distributions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use random sampling to draw inferences about a population.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Develop a probability model (which may not be uniform) by observing frequencies in data generated from a chance process.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that, just as with simple events, the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which the compound event occurs.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent sample spaces for compound events using methods such as organized lists, tables and tree diagrams. For an event described in everyday language (e.g., "rolling double sixes"), identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data to investigate patterns of association between two quantities. Describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables. For scatter plots that suggest a linear association, informally fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by judging the closeness of the data points to the line.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and intercept.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that patterns of association can also be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe possible association between the two variables.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Investigate patterns of association in bivariate data.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output. The graph of a function is the set of ordered pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function, whose graph is a straight line; give examples of functions that are not linear.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Define, evaluate, and compare functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing a graph (e.g., where the function is increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a function that has been described verbally.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use functions to model relationships between quantities.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Explain how the definition of the meaning of rational exponents follows from extending the properties of integer exponents to those values, allowing for a notation for radicals in terms of rational exponents.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Extend the properties of exponents to rational exponents.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an irrational number is irrational.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use properties of rational and irrational numbers.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: The Real Number System
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Reason quantitatively and use units to solve problems.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Quantities
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Know there is a complex number i such that i = -1, and every complex number has the form a + bi with a and b real.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the relation i = -1 and the commutative, associative, and distributive properties to add, subtract, and multiply complex numbers.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Find the conjugate of a complex number; use conjugates to find moduli and quotients of complex numbers.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Perform arithmetic operations with complex numbers.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Represent complex numbers on the complex plane in rectangular and polar form (including real and imaginary numbers), and explain why the rectangular and polar forms of a given complex number represent the same number.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Represent addition, subtraction, multiplication, and conjugation of complex numbers geometrically on the complex plane; use properties of this representation for computation.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Calculate the distance between numbers in the complex plane as the modulus of the difference, and the midpoint of a segment as the average of the numbers at its endpoints.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent complex numbers and their operations on the complex plane.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve quadratic equations with real coefficients that have complex solutions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Extend polynomial identities to the complex numbers.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Know the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra; show that it is true for quadratic polynomials.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use complex numbers in polynomial identities and equations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: The Complex Number System
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Recognize vector quantities as having both magnitude and direction. Represent vector quantities by directed line segments, and use appropriate symbols for vectors and their magnitudes (e.g., v, |v|, ||v||, v).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Find the components of a vector by subtracting the coordinates of an initial point from the coordinates of a terminal point.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Solve problems involving velocity and other quantities that can be represented by vectors.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent and model with vector quantities.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Add vectors end-to-end, component-wise, and by the parallelogram rule. Understand that the magnitude of a sum of two vectors is typically not the sum of the magnitudes.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Given two vectors in magnitude and direction form, determine the magnitude and direction of their sum.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand vector subtraction v - w as v + (-w), where -w is the additive inverse of w, with the same magnitude as w and pointing in the opposite direction. Represent vector subtraction graphically by connecting the tips in the appropriate order, and perform vector subtraction component-wise.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Add and subtract vectors.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent scalar multiplication graphically by scaling vectors and possibly reversing their direction; perform scalar multiplication component-wise, e.g., as c(v<sub>x</sub>, v<sub>y</sub>) = (cv<sub>x</sub>, cv<sub>y</sub>).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Compute the magnitude of a scalar multiple cv using ||cv|| = |c|v. Compute the direction of cv knowing that when |c|v ? 0, the direction of cv is either along v (for c > 0) or against v (for c < 0).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Multiply a vector by a scalar.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Perform operations on vectors.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Use matrices to represent and manipulate data, e.g., to represent payoffs or incidence relationships in a network.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Multiply matrices by scalars to produce new matrices, e.g., as when all of the payoffs in a game are doubled.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Add, subtract, and multiply matrices of appropriate dimensions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Understand that, unlike multiplication of numbers, matrix multiplication for square matrices is not a commutative operation, but still satisfies the associative and distributive properties.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Understand that the zero and identity matrices play a role in matrix addition and multiplication similar to the role of 0 and 1 in the real numbers. The determinant of a square matrix is nonzero if and only if the matrix has a multiplicative inverse.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Multiply a vector (regarded as a matrix with one column) by a matrix of suitable dimensions to produce another vector. Work with matrices as transformations of vectors.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Work with 2  2 matrices as transformations of the plane, and interpret the absolute value of the determinant in terms of area.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Vector and Matrix Quantities
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret parts of an expression, such as terms, factors, and coefficients.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret complicated expressions by viewing one or more of their parts as a single entity.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms of its context
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret the structure of expressions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function it defines.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Complete the square in a quadratic expression to reveal the maximum or minimum value of the function it defines.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series (when the common ratio is not 1), and use the formula to solve problems.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Seeing Structure in Expressions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Perform arithmetic operations on polynomials
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Know and apply the Remainder Theorem: For a polynomial p(x) and a number a, the remainder on division by x - a is p(a), so p(a) = 0 if and only if (x - a) is a factor of p(x).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Identify zeros of polynomials when suitable factorizations are available, and use the zeros to construct a rough graph of the function defined by the polynomial.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand the relationship between zeros and factors of polynomials
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove polynomial identities and use them to describe numerical relationships.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Know and apply the Binomial Theorem for the expansion of (x + y)<sup>n</sup> in powers of x and y for a positive integer n, where x and y are any numbers, with coefficients determined for example by Pascal's Triangle.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use polynomial identities to solve problems
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms; write <sup>a(x </sup>/<sub>b(x)</sub> in the form q(x) + <sup>r(x)</sup>/<sub>b(x)</sub>, where a(x), b(x), q(x), and r(x) are polynomials with the degree of r(x) less than the degree of b(x), using inspection, long division, or, for the more complicated examples, a computer algebra system.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Understand that rational expressions form a system analogous to the rational numbers, closed under addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by a nonzero rational expression; add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational expressions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Rewrite rational expressions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. Include equations arising from linear and quadratic functions, and simple rational and exponential functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent constraints by equations or inequalities, and by systems of equations and/or inequalities, and interpret solutions as viable or nonviable options in a modeling context.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest, using the same reasoning as in solving equations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Creating Equations
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to justify a solution method.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable, and give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the method of completing the square to transform any quadratic equation in x into an equation of the form (x - p) = q that has the same solutions. Derive the quadratic formula from this form.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve quadratic equations by inspection (e.g., for x = 49), taking square roots, completing the square, the quadratic formula and factoring, as appropriate to the initial form of the equation. Recognize when the quadratic formula gives complex solutions and write them as a  bi for real numbers a and b.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove that, given a system of two equations in two variables, replacing one equation by the sum of that equation and a multiple of the other produces a system with the same solutions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear equations in two variables.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Represent a system of linear equations as a single matrix equation in a vector variable.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Find the inverse of a matrix if it exists and use it to solve systems of linear equations (using technology for matrices of dimension 3  3 or greater).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve systems of equations
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane, often forming a curve (which could be a line).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Explain why the x-coordinates of the points where the graphs of the equations y = f(x) and y = g(x) intersect are the solutions of the equation f(x) = g(x); find the solutions approximately, e.g., using technology to graph the functions, make tables of values, or find successive approximations. Include cases where f(x) and/or g(x) are linear, polynomial, rational, absolute value, exponential, and logarithmic functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Reasoning with Equations and Inequalities
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range. If f is a function and x is an element of its domain, then f(x) denotes the output of f corresponding to the input x. The graph of f is the graph of the equation y = f(x).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: For a function that models a relationship between two quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal description of the relationship.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified interval. Estimate the rate of change from a graph.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Graph linear and quadratic functions and show intercepts, maxima, and minima.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Graph square root, cube root, and piecewise-defined functions, including step functions and absolute value functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Graph polynomial functions, identifying zeros when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Graph rational functions, identifying zeros and asymptotes when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Graph exponential and logarithmic functions, showing intercepts and end behavior, and trigonometric functions, showing period, midline, and amplitude.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the process of factoring and completing the square in a quadratic function to show zeros, extreme values, and symmetry of the graph, and interpret these in terms of a context.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the properties of exponents to interpret expressions for exponential functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Write a function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Analyze functions using different representations
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpreting Functions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Determine an explicit expression, a recursive process, or steps for calculation from a context.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Combine standard function types using arithmetic operations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Compose functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula, use them to model situations, and translate between the two forms.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Identify the effect on the graph of replacing f(x) by f(x) + k, k f(x), f(kx), and f(x + k) for specific values of k (both positive and negative); find the value of k given the graphs. Experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the graph using technology. Include recognizing even and odd functions from their graphs and algebraic expressions for them.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Solve an equation of the form f(x) = c for a simple function f that has an inverse and write an expression for the inverse.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Verify by composition that one function is the inverse of another.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Read values of an inverse function from a graph or a table, given that the function has an inverse.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Produce an invertible function from a non-invertible function by restricting the domain.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Find inverse functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Understand the inverse relationship between exponents and logarithms and use this relationship to solve problems involving logarithms and exponents.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Build new functions from existing functions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Building Functions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove that linear functions grow by equal differences over equal intervals, and that exponential functions grow by equal factors over equal intervals.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Recognize situations in which one quantity changes at a constant rate per unit interval relative to another.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Recognize situations in which a quantity grows or decays by a constant percent rate per unit interval relative to another.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (include reading these from a table).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Observe using graphs and tables that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity increasing linearly, quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: For exponential models, express as a logarithm the solution to ab<sup>ct</sup> = d where a, c, and d are numbers and the base b is 2, 10, or e; evaluate the logarithm using technology.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function in terms of a context.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret expressions for functions in terms of the situation they model
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Linear, Quadratic, and Exponential Models
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand radian measure of an angle as the length of the arc on the unit circle subtended by the angle.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Explain how the unit circle in the coordinate plane enables the extension of trigonometric functions to all real numbers, interpreted as radian measures of angles traversed counterclockwise around the unit circle.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Use special triangles to determine geometrically the values of sine, cosine, tangent for /3, /4 and /6, and use the unit circle to express the values of sine, cosine, and tangent for -x, +x, and 2-x in terms of their values for x, where x is any real number.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Use the unit circle to explain symmetry (odd and even) and periodicity of trigonometric functions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Choose trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena with specified amplitude, frequency, and midline.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Understand that restricting a trigonometric function to a domain on which it is always increasing or always decreasing allows its inverse to be constructed.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Use inverse functions to solve trigonometric equations that arise in modeling contexts; evaluate the solutions using technology, and interpret them in terms of the context.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Model periodic phenomena with trigonometric functions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove the Pythagorean identity sin() + cos() = 1 and use it to find sin(), cos(), or tan() given sin(), cos(), or tan() and the quadrant of the angle.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Prove the addition and subtraction formulas for sine, cosine, and tangent and use them to solve problems.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove and apply trigonometric identities
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Trigonometric Functions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Know precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point, line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using, e.g., graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Experiment with transformations in the plane
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Explain how the criteria for triangle congruence (ASA, SAS, and SSS) follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove theorems about lines and angles.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove theorems about triangles.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove theorems about parallelograms.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove geometric theorems
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.). Copying a segment; copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Make geometric constructions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Congruence
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: A dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the dilation to a parallel line, and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: The dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter in the ratio given by the scale factor.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Given two figures, use the definition of similarity in terms of similarity transformations to decide if they are similar; explain using similarity transformations the meaning of similarity for triangles as the equality of all corresponding pairs of angles and the proportionality of all corresponding pairs of sides.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove theorems about triangles.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove theorems involving similarity
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Explain and use the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Derive the formula A = 1/2 ab sin(C) for the area of a triangle by drawing an auxiliary line from a vertex perpendicular to the opposite side.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Prove the Laws of Sines and Cosines and use them to solve problems.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Understand and apply the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines to find unknown measurements in right and non-right triangles (e.g., surveying problems, resultant forces).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Apply trigonometry to general triangles
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Similarity, Right Triangles, and Trigonometry
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove that all circles are similar.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle, and prove properties of angles for a quadrilateral inscribed in a circle.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Construct a tangent line from a point outside a given circle to the circle.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand and apply theorems about circles
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Find arc lengths and areas of sectors of circles
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Circles
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Derive the equation of a parabola given a focus and directrix.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Derive the equations of ellipses and hyperbolas given the foci, using the fact that the sum or difference of distances from the foci is constant.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic section
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles, e.g., using the distance formula.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Expressing Geometric Properties with Equations
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Give an informal argument using Cavalieri's principle for the formulas for the volume of a sphere and other solid figures.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Explain volume formulas and use them to solve problems
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Identify the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional objects, and identify three-dimensional objects generated by rotations of two-dimensional objects.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Visualize relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Geometric Measurement and Dimension
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe objects (e.g., modeling a tree trunk or a human torso as a cylinder).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Apply concepts of density based on area and volume in modeling situations (e.g., persons per square mile, BTUs per cubic foot).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Apply geometric methods to solve design problems (e.g., designing an object or structure to satisfy physical constraints or minimize cost; working with typographic grid systems based on ratios).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Apply geometric concepts in modeling situations
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Modeling with Geometry
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots, histograms, and box plots).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects of extreme data points (outliers).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the mean and standard deviation of a data set to fit it to a normal distribution and to estimate population percentages. Recognize that there are data sets for which such a procedure is not appropriate. Use calculators, spreadsheets, and tables to estimate areas under the normal curve.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Fit a function to the data; use functions fitted to data to solve problems in the context of the data.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Informally assess the fit of a function by plotting and analyzing residuals.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Fit a linear function for a scatter plot that suggests a linear association.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Distinguish between correlation and causation.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpret linear models
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Interpreting Categorical and Quantitative Data
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand statistics as a process for making inferences about population parameters based on a random sample from that population.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Decide if a specified model is consistent with results from a given data-generating process, e.g., using simulation.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand and evaluate random processes underlying statistical experiments
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Recognize the purposes of and differences among sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies; explain how randomization relates to each.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use data from a sample survey to estimate a population mean or proportion; develop a margin of error through the use of simulation models for random sampling.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use data from a randomized experiment to compare two treatments; use simulations to decide if differences between parameters are significant.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Evaluate reports based on data.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Make inferences and justify conclusions from sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Making Inferences and Justifying Conclusions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Describe events as subsets of a sample space (the set of outcomes) using characteristics (or categories) of the outcomes, or as unions, intersections, or complements of other events ("or," "and," "not").
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand that two events A and B are independent if the probability of A and B occurring together is the product of their probabilities, and use this characterization to determine if they are independent.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand the conditional probability of A given B as P(A and B)/P(B), and interpret independence of A and B as saying that the conditional probability of A given B is the same as the probability of A, and the conditional probability of B given A is the same as the probability of B.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Recognize and explain the concepts of conditional probability and independence in everyday language and everyday situations.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Understand independence and conditional probability and use them to interpret data
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B's outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Apply the Addition Rule, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Apply the general Multiplication Rule in a uniform probability model, P(A and B) = P(A)P(B|A) = P(B)P(A|B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Use permutations and combinations to compute probabilities of compound events and solve problems.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use the rules of probability to compute probabilities of compound events in a uniform probability model
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Define a random variable for a quantity of interest by assigning a numerical value to each event in a sample space; graph the corresponding probability distribution using the same graphical displays as for data distributions.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Calculate the expected value of a random variable; interpret it as the mean of the probability distribution.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which theoretical probabilities can be calculated; find the expected value.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which probabilities are assigned empirically; find the expected value.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Calculate expected values and use them to solve problems
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Find the expected payoff for a game of chance.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Evaluate and compare strategies on the basis of expected values.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Weigh the possible outcomes of a decision by assigning probabilities to payoff values and finding expected values.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Use probabilities to make fair decisions (e.g., drawing by lots, using a random number generator).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: (+) Analyze decisions and strategies using probability concepts (e.g., product testing, medical testing, pulling a hockey goalie at the end of a game).
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Using Probability to Make Decisions
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Model with mathematics.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Use appropriate tools strategically.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Attend to precision.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Look for and make use of structure.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math

children.description: Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.
children.subject: http://purl.org/ASN/scheme/ASNTopic/math
